<<<api>>>: StringTokenizer.nextToken
<<<code>>>: public class TestStringTokenizer {
```arduino
public static void main(String[] args) {
    String input = "USA UK USSR China";
    String[] pairs = new String[input.length() / 2];
    int i = 0;
    StringTokenizer st = new StringTokenizer(input, " ");
    while (st.hasMoreTokens()) {
        pairs[i] = st.nextToken();
        i++;
    }
    for (int j = 0; j < pairs.length; j++) {
        System.out.println(pairs[j]);
    }
}
```
}

Explanation:
The above code uses a StringTokenizer to split the input string into words using the space as the delimiter. It then uses an array to store the pairs of words and iterates over the array to print out each pair. The length of the array is calculated by dividing the length of the input string by 2, assuming that each pair of words is separated by a space. The hasMoreTokens() method is used to check if there are more tokens to be extracted from the input string, and the nextToken() method is used to extract each token from the input string and store it in the array.
